More generally, whenever a set S contains a nonzero vector \Vect{x} and fits inside some box, S cannot be closed under addition. Why? Adding up sufficiently many copies of x yields a vector outside of S.

problem.para: If V and W are subspaces of \RNr[n], show that the union of V and W need not be a subvector space of \RNr[n].

solution.hint.para: The problem asks you to show that not every pair V and W of subspaces of \RNr[n] has the property that the union of V and W is a subspace of \RNr[n].
It is sufficient to find a number n and then two specific subspaces V and W of \RNr[n] whose union is not a subspace.
It is possible to show this for n=2.
In \RNr[2], let V be the x-axis, and let W be the y-axis. Is the union of V and W closed under vector addition?
